ctg <- new("LAScatalog")

A LAScatalog class is a representation in R of a file or a set of las files not loaded in memory. Indeed, a regular computer cannot load an entire point cloud into R if it covers a wide area. For very high density files it can even fail when loading a single file (see also the "LAS formal class"" vignette). In lidR, we use a LAScatalog to process datasets that cannot fit in memory.

## Build a LAScatalog object reading a folder of las files

```r
ctg <- catalog("path/to/las/files/")
# or
ctg <- catalog("path/to/las/files/big_file.las")
```

```{r}
print(ctg)
```

## Basic structure of a LAScatalog object

A LAScatalog inherits a SpatialPolygonsDataFrame. Thus, it has the structure of a SpatialPolygonsDataFrame plus some extra slots that store information relative to how the LAScatalog will be processed.

The slot `data` of a LAScatalog object contains a `data.frame` with the most important information read only from the header of .las or .laz files. Reading only the file header allows users to get an overview of the content of the files very quickly without actually loading the point cloud. The columns of the table are named after the [LAS specification](http://www.asprs.org/wp-content/uploads/2010/12/LAS_1_4_r13.pdf) version 1.4.

The other slots are covered in detail in the documentation ?\`LAScatalog-class\` so are not described in this vignette.

## Allowed and non-allowed manipulation of a LAScatalog object

A LAScatalog is formally a SpatialPolygonsDataFrame but its purpose is not to manipulate spatial data in R. The purpose of a LAScatalog is to represent a set of existing las/laz files. Thus, a LAScatalog cannot be modified because it must be related to the actual content of the files. The following throws an error:

```{r, error = TRUE, purl = FALSE}
ctg$Min.Z <- 0
```

Obviously it is always possible to bypass the simple restrictions in order to modify an R object. In that case the user will break something internally and a correct output is not guaranteed.

## Validation of LAScatalog object

It is common for users to report bugs arising from the fact that the point cloud is invalid. This is why we introduced the function `lascheck` to perform an inspection of the LAScatalog objects. This function checks whether a LAScatalog object is consistent (e.g. files are all of the same type). For example, it could be that a catalog contains files of both type 1 and type 3, or files with different scale factors.

```{r}
lascheck(ctg)
```

When applied to a catalog, the function `lascheck` does not perform a deep inspection of the point cloud, unlike when it is applied to a LAS object. In fact the point cloud is not actually read.

## Display a LAScatalog object

lidR provides a simple `plot` function to plot a LAScatalog object:

```{r, fig.width=4, fig.height=4}
plot(ctg)
```

The option `mapview = TRUE` displays the catalog on an interactive map with pan and zoom, and allows a satellite map to be added in background. It uses the package `mapview` internally. It is often useful to check if the CRS of a file is properly registered. In our experience, the epsg code of the las file often appears to be inccorect.

```r
plot(ctg, mapview = TRUE, map.type = "Esri.WorldImagery")
```

```{r, echo = FALSE, fig.width=4, fig.height=4}
plot(ctg, map = TRUE)@map
```

Because it is a SpatialPolygonsDataFrame, the function `spplot` from `sp` can be used on a LAScatalog to check the contents of the files. In the following example we can immediately see that the catalog is not normalized and is likely to contain outliers:

```{r, fig.width=4, fig.height=4}
spplot(ctg, "Min.Z")
```

## Apply lidR functions on a LAScatalog

Most of the functions in lidR are compatible with a LAScatalog and work almost the same as with a point cloud loaded in memory. In the following example we use the function `grid_metrics` to compute the mean elevation of the points. The output is a continuous wall-to-wall RasterLayer. It works exactly as if the input was a LAS object.

```r
hmean <- grid_metrics(ctg, mean(Z), 20)
```
However, processing a LAScatalog usually requires tuning of some processing options to get finer control of the computation. Indeed, if the catalog is huge the output is also likely to be huge and it might not fit in R memory. For example, `lasnormalize` throws an error if used 'as is' without tuning the processing options. Using `lasnormalize` as in the following example the expected `output` would be a huge point cloud loaded in memory. The lidR package forbids a call such as:

```{r, error = TRUE, purl = FALSE}
output <- lasnormalize(ctg, tin())
```

Instead one can use the processing option `opt_output_files`. Processing options control how large files are split into smaller chunks and how the outputs are either returned into R or written into files on disk.

```r
opt_output_file(ctg) <- "folder/where/to/store/outputs/{ORIGINALFILENAME}_normalized"
output <- lasnormalize(ctg, tin())
```
Here the output is not a point cloud but a LAScatalog pointing to the newly-created files. Users can check how the catalog will be processed by calling `summary`:

```{r}
summary(ctg)
```

Also the `plot` function can display the chunks pattern i.e. how the dataset is split into small chunks that will be sequentially processed


```{r, fig.show='hold'}
opt_chunk_size(ctg) <- 0
plot(ctg, chunk = TRUE)

opt_chunk_size(ctg) <- 900
plot(ctg, chunk = TRUE)
```

Below are some practical examples.

#### Example 1 - Raster

Load a catalog. Process each file sequentially. Returns a RasterLayer into R.

```r
ctg <- catalog("path/to/las/files/")
hmean <- grid_metrics(ctg, mean(Z), 20)
```

#### Example 2 - Raster

Load a catalog, process each file sequentially. For each file write a raster on disk named after the filename of the processed files. Returns a lightweight virtual raster mosaic.

```r
ctg <- catalog("path/to/las/files/")
opt_output_files(ctg) <- "folder/where/to/store/outputs/dtm_{ORIGINALFILENAME}"
dtm <- grid_terrain(ctg, tin())
```

#### Example 3 - Raster

Load a single large file that is too big to be loaded into memory. Process small chunks of 100 x 100 meters at a time. Returns a RasterLayer into R.

```r
ctg <- catalog("path/to/las/files/bigfile.las")
opt_chunk_size(ctg) <- 100
chm <- grid_canopy(ctg, p2r())
```

#### Example 4 - Tree detection

Load a catalog. Process small chunks of 200 x 200 meters at a time. Each chunk is loaded with an extra 20 m buffer. Use 3 cores. Returns a Shapefile into R.

```r
ctg <- catalog("path/to/las/files/")
opt_chunk_size(ctg) <- 200
opt_chunk_buffer(ctg) <- 20
opt_cores(ctg) <- 3
ttops <- tree_detection(ctg, lmf(5))
```

#### Example 5 - Decimate

This is forbidden. The output would be too big.


```r
ctg <- catalog("path/to/las/files/")
decimated <- lasfilterdecimate(ctg, homogenize(4))
```

#### Example 6 - Decimate

Load a catalog, process small 500 x 500-m chunks sequentially. For each chunk write a laz file on disk named after the coordinates of the chunk. Returns a lightweight LAScatalog. Notice that the original catalog has been retiled.

```r
ctg <- catalog("path/to/las/files/")
opt_chunk_size(ctg) <- 500
opt_output_files(ctg) <- "folder/where/to/store/outputs/project_{XLEFT}_{YBOTTOM}_decimated"
opt_laz_compression(ctg) <- TRUE
decimated <- lasfilterdecimate(ctg, homogenize(4))
```

#### Example 7 - Clip

Load a catalog. Load a shapefile of plot centers. Extract the plots and return a list of extracted point clouds in R.

```r
ctg <- catalog("path/to/las/files/")
shp <- shapefile("plot_center.shp")
plots <- lasclip(ctg, shp, radius = 11.2)
```

#### Example 8 - Clip

Load a catalog. Load a shapefile of plot centers. Extract the plots and immediately write them to a file named after the coordinates of the plot and an attribute of the shapefile (here `FORESTTYPE`, if such attribute exists in the shapefile). Returns a lightweight LAScatalog.

```r
ctg <- catalog("path/to/las/files/")
shp <- shapefile("plot_center.shp")
opt_output_files(ctg) <- "folder/where/to/store/outputs/plot_{XCENTER}_{YCENTER}_{PLOTID}"
plots <- lasclip(ctg, plot_centers, radius = 11.2)
```
